Berries: Tea drunk to cure respiratory problems [Dene: 101].

Vernacular name(s): red clover (Eng.); trèfle des prés, trèfle rouge (Fr.)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Tea used for whooping cough [Algonquin: 69].

Vernacular name(s): seaside arrow-grass (Eng.); troscart maritime, faux jonc (Fr.); minahikos (Cree)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Whole plant: Boiled and the decoction drunk to relieve bloody diarrhoea [Cree: 13].

Vernacular name(s): bethroot, red trillium (Eng.); trille dressé, trille rouge (Fr.); dzidziz (Abenaki)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Rhizomes and roots: Used for "women complaints" [44] and various child diseases [Abenaki: 67]. Freshly cut, and the acridity inhaled for nostril bleeding [44].

Vernacular name(s): white trillium (Eng.); trille blanc, trille grandiflore (Fr.); inĭ'nĭwĭn'dĭbĭge'gûn (Ojibwa)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Roots: Infusion of inner bark of root dropped in the ear to treat soreness. Decoction taken in rheumatism [Ojibwa: 47].

Vernacular name(s): painted trillium (Eng.); trille ondulé (Fr.); penadamabaskw (Atikamekw)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Flowers and leaves: Crushed and the pulp eaten to accelerate childbirth [Atikamekw: 73].

Vernacular name(s): horse gentian (Eng.); trioste orangé (Fr.); moninswan (Ojibwa)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Roots: Decoction used for urinary pain, as a diuretic, or as a laxative [Ojibwa: 19].

Vernacular name(s): eastern hemlock (Eng.); prûche (Fr.); ksiusk (Malecite); gaga'gimĭc (Ojibwa); al'nézité (Abenaki)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Tea used for cold, boiled and applied externally for eczema and other skin infections. Used in the sudatory for women experiencing complications in childbirth [Algonquin: 69].

Bark: Tea used in cold, cough and grippe [Mi'kmaq: 43, 60]. Used to heal cuts and wounds [Ojibwa: 87, 91]. Tea used to relieve cold [Mi'kmaq: 62]. Mixed with buds or young cones of Abies balsamea, and bark of Quercus rubra and used for diarrhoea [Malecite: 65].
Leaves: Used for rheumatism, itching or scabies [Abenaki: 67].
Roots: Steeped with Conioselium chinense, Chimaphila umbellate, and Rumex crispus and given in bladder problems [Mi'kmaq: 62].

Twigs: Steeped to make a drink as a remedy for dysentery [Ojibwa: 85]. Tea, thick syrup or paste used as a poultice for arthritis. Crushed to make a poultice for the infected navel of an infant [Algonquin: 69].
Inner bark: Powdered and applied to wounds to stop bleeding [Ojibwa: 47]. Tea used for pain and cold [Mi'kmaq: 91].
Wood: Dried and used in prickly heat or chafed skin [Malecite: 65].

Vernacular name(s): cat-tail flag (Eng.); quenouille (Fr.); ba'ziask (Malecite)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Roots: Steeped and taken in gravel [Malecite: 65].

Vernacular name(s): cattail (Eng.); massette, quenouille (Fr.); otawuskwa, ōtawaskwa, ā(h)towusk, wahōtāhuk, pāsīhkan (Cree); segidebigakde'gil (Malecite); tl'okàwhi (Dene); tlh'oghk'a (Chipewyan)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Seeds: Dried and used as a poultice for burns [Cree, Metis: 13]. Poultice used in skin disorders, cuts, burns and bee stings [Cree: 96].
Leaves: Greased and layed on a sore twice a day [Malecite: 65].

Roots: Used in diabetes [Cree: 83]. Crushed by pounding or chewing and applied as a poultice to sores [Ojibwa: 84]. Poultice applied to wounds and infections [Algonquin: 69]. Boiled and used to wash skin infections. Compress applied to treat sore throat [Cree: 80]. Medicinal [Chipewyan: 92].
Stalk: Burned and the ashes applied to a skin rash, towel soaked in tea and applied to cure urinary tract problems [Dene: 101].

Vernacular name(s): American elm (Eng.); orme d'Amérique (Fr.)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Bark: Steeped and drunk as a cure for lung bleeding [Algonquians: 63].

Vernacular name(s): slippery elm (Eng.); orme rouge (Fr.) ah-nib, gawa'komĭc (Ojibwa)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Used in gonorrhoea [Ojibwa: 86].

Bark: Used for lung bleeding. Used to soothe irritated throat and lungs. Used for suppurating wounds [Mi'kmaq: 60]. Decoction used for infected kidneys or as a gargle to treat ulcerated throat [Ojibwa: 47, 91].
Inner bark: Chewed fresh for cough [44]. Used for sore throat [Ojibwa: 87].
Roots: Chewed dry to treat sore throat [Ojibwa: 47].

Vernacular name(s): lichen (Eng.); tripe de roche (Fr.); asinewakunik (Atikamekw)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Softened in boiling water and applied to stomach of women having difficulty giving birth [Atikamekw: 73].

Vernacular name(s): rock tripe (Eng.); thets'ín. (Chipewyan); asinīwāhkona, wakoonak, asinīwākon (Cree); kwechį (Dene)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Chewed or dried, powdered, and boiled to make asyrup taken against tapeworms [Dene: 13; Chipewyan: 92]. Decoction used in stomachache [Cree: 13]. Soup eaten as a tonic and for breathing problems [Dene: 101].

Latin name, Botanical family and Growth: Urtica dioica L. ssp. gracilis (Aiton) Seland.
Vernacular name(s): nettle (Eng.); ortie élevée (Fr.); masan, ma'zana'tĭg, (Ojibwa); katsékô'sag (Abenaki)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Used for nosebleed [Abenaki: 67].

Latin name, Botanical family and Growth: Syn.: U. lyallii S. Watson; U. procera Muhl. ex Willd
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Roots: Decoction, alone or with Athyrium filix-femina, used to treat stoppage of urine. Steeped and taken in dysentry [Chippewa: 47]. Used as a wash in skin disorders, cuts, burns and bee stings [Cree: 96]. Herbal water taken for back paralysis, fever and urinary tract problems [Cree: 93].
Leaves: Soaked in warm water and used as a poultice for heat rashes [Ojibwa: 87].
Leaves and stems: Herbal water taken for anemia [Cree: 93].

Vernacular name(s): stinging nettle (Eng.); ortie (Fr.); masān, musān, musanusk, assan, masānah (Cree)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Decoction used to keep blood flowing after childbirth [Cree: 95].
Leaves: Decoction used as a face wash to treat acne [Cree: 13] and drunk to treat diarrhoea or intestinal worms [Dene: 13].

Roots: Decoction used as a wash to relieve itching and inflammation caused by touching stinging leaves [Cree: 13], drunk as a blood purifier, to stop internal bleeding, to correct menstrual flow, or to clear phlegm from the lungs and throat [Dene: 13]. Boiled and the steam inhaled to treat asthma [Cree: 13].

Vernacular name(s): miyapakwan, mithapakonuk (Cree)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Used to pack nostril to stop nosebleed [Dene: 13]

Vernacular name(s): old man's beard moss (Eng.); mithāpākwan (Cree)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Inserted fresh into the nostril to stop nosebleed [Cree: 95].

Vernacular name(s): bladderwort (Eng.); utriculaire commune (Fr.)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Whole plant: Tea used to treat kidney or bladder infection [Dene: 100]. Boiled and washed to treat sore legs [Dene: 98].
Leaves: Tea used to treat kidney or bladder infection [Dene: 100].

Vernacular name(s): large flowered bellwort (Eng.); uvulaire grandiflore (Fr.); wesawabi'kwonêk (Ojibwa)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Roots: Used for stomach troubles [Ojibwa: 87].

Vernacular name(s): late sweet blueberry, low-bush blueberry (Eng); airelle à feuilles étroites, bleuet (Fr.); mînûga'wunj, mĭna'aga'wûnj (Ojibwa)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Used to treat "crazyness" [Ojibwa: 47].
Leaves: Tea used as a blood purifier [Ojibwa: 87], to treat colic and given after miscarriage [Algonquin: 69].
Roots: Tea given to induce labor during childbirth [Algonquin: 69]. Used to treat urinary problems [Algonquin: 68]. Used in diabetes [Cree: 82, 83].
Fruits: Used in diabetes [Cree: 82, 83].

Vernacular name(s): cranberry (Eng.); airelle à gros fruits, gros atocas (Fr.)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Twigs: Steeped and used as a medicine for pleurisy [Algonquians: 63].

Vernacular name(s): blueberry, bilberry, whortle berry, huckleberry (Eng.); airelle fausse-myrtille, bleuet (Fr.); inimena, īyinimin, iynimin, ithīnīmina, sīpīkōmin (Cree); ts'anlhchoth (Chipewyan)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Whole plant: Component of an anticancer medicine [Metis: 13].
Fruits: Helps to reduce acne. Syrup used to stop vomiting [Metis: 13].

Stem: Boiled to make a drink taken to prevent pregnancy or in combination with other plants to prevent miscarriage, bring blood after childbirth, trigger menstruation, or slow excessive menstruation [Metis, Cree: 13].
Leaves: Decoction taken for headache [Dene: 13]. Steeped and applied for rheumatism [Mi'kmaq: 62].
Roots: Tea drunk for headache [Chhipewyan: 92]. Herbal water used to ease childbirth [Cree: 93].

Vernacular name(s): cranberry (Eng.); canneberge, atocas (Fr.); mûcki'mûnj (Ojibwa)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Tea drunk to treat nausea [Ojibwa: 87].

Vernacular name(s): alpine bilberry, bog blueberry (Eng.); airelle des marécages (Fr.); jàk zheii (Dene)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Stem and leaves: Boiled to make a tea for cold [Dene: 99].
Berries: Eaten raw or made into a tea taken in diabetes or in heart problems [Dene: 100].

Vernacular name(s): bog cranberry, cowberry, lingonberry (Eng.); airelle vigne d'Ida, berris, graines rouges (Fr.); wesakemina, wīsaki(h)min, wiysukiymin (Cree); uîshatshiminânakashî (Montagnais); natl'at (Dene) ; nantlh'ër (Chipewyan)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Fruits: Used for stomach cleansing [Cree: 13], fever [Dene: 13; Chipewyan: 92], diabetes [Cree: 82, 83], mouth infections in children, and throat pain [Montagnais: 71]. Cooked to make a jam used for diarrhoea. Juice used to dampen contractions during childbirth [Montagnais: 71]. Juice taken for kidney problems, cough and cold, indigestion, and to improve appetite [Dene: 99]. Chewed or boiled to ease cough and cold [Dene: 101].
Roots and stems: Boiled and the decoction drunk to treat bladder problems [Cree: 13].
Whole plant and fruits: Tea drunk to treat kidney or urinary tract problems [Dene: 100].

Vernacular name(s): northern valerian (Eng.); valériane (Fr.); upistagiwasus, apiscisakōwaskwos, apiscakāwaskwos, apisichīsakwasosuk, apiscīsakwīwaskwos, āpisagiywuskos (Cree)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Whole plant: Dried, boiled and the decoction drunk to treat a sore aching body, cold, chill, and congestion, helping clear the air passages [Cree: 13].

Leaves: Decoction given to a child who has lost weight to help gain weight [Cree: 13]. Decoction given to prevent miscarriage or to ease labor pain [Cree: 13]. Dried, crushed, mixed with beaver fat and applied as an ointment on facial rashes [Cree: 13].
Stem and leaves: Boiled with another plant and drunk to treat cold or fever [Cree: 13].

Roots: Decoction from a plant that has not flowered is considered a very powerful tonic. If abused it will make user very sick [Cree: 13]. Chewed to treat severe heart trouble [Cree, Metis: 13], also helps to prevent aging and wrinkles and keep active [Cree: 13].

Latin name, Botanical family and Growth: Valeriana dioica L. var. sylvatica S. Watson
Vernacular name(s): northern valerian, wood valerian (Eng.); valériane nordique (Fr.); apiscīsakwīwaskwos (Cree)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Roots: Chewed, put into a cloth and placed in the ear to treat earache, and rubbed on the head and temples to treat headache. Applied externally in case of seizure. Powdered, used as an ingredient for many ailments and to treat menstrual troubles. Infusion used for all purposes. Decoction used for pneumonia and in a smoking mixture for colds [Cree: 95]. Chewed or prepared as a tea for heart problems. Tea taken as a tonic and blood cleanser [Cree: 96].

Latin name, Botanical family and Growth: Syn.: V. sylvatica Sol. ex Richardson, non F.W. Schmidt V. septentrionalis Rydb.

Vernacular name(s): false or indian hellebore (Eng.); vérâtre vert, tabac du diable, hellébore (Fr.)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Roots: Febrifugal, depressant and stirnutatory [Cree: 74]. Used as an emetic [Dene: 98].

Vernacular name(s): mullein (Eng.); molène vulgaire, tabac du diable (Fr.); tcuglsia'sihonel (Malecite); mandando'hibag (Abenaki)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Necklace for teething babies [Abenaki: 67].
Leaves: Powdered and smoked to cure asthma [Algonquians: 63]. Applied to sores, cuts, and catarrh [Malecite: 65]. Steeped and smelled to relieve asthma [Mi'kmaq: 62].
Roots: Used as an expectorant [66].

Vernacular name(s): blue vervain (Eng.); verveine hastée (Fr.)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Flowers: Dried and snuffed to stop nostril bleeding [Ojibwa: 47].

Vernacular name(s): culver's root (Eng.); véronique de Virginie (Fr.); wi'sŏgedzhi'wik, wi'sûgidji'bĭk (Ojibwa)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Roots: Decoction taken as a purgative [Ojibwa: 44, 84] and a physic [Ojibwa: 47]. Decoction with bark of Prunus virginiana taken before breakfast to treat scrofula [Ojibwa: 47].

Latin name, Botanical family and Growth: Syn.: Leptandra virginica (L.) Nutt. V. virginica L.

Vernacular name(s): mapleleaf viburnum (Eng.); viorne à feuilles d'érable (Fr.); anib' (Ojibwa)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Inner bark: Decoction to treat stomach cramps. Decoction, alone or with Almus incana, used as an emetic [Ojibwa: 47].

Vernacular name(s): pembina, squashberry, mooseberry, low bush-cranberry, (Eng.); viorne comestible, pimbina (Fr.); moosomina, mōsomina, moosominahtik, mōsōminā(h)tik (Cree); deníjíé (Chipewyan)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Ingredient in a gargle for sore throat [Cree: 95]. Tea used as a blood purifier [Metis: 13].

Latin name, Botanical family and Growth: Syn.: V. pauciflorum La Pylaie ex Torr. & A. Gray
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Twig: Tips chewed to treat sore throat [Dene: 13, Cree: 95].
Buds: Unopened buds rubbed on sore lips to heal and dry [Cree: 95; Dene: 13].

Roots: Tea used to ease teething pain [Dene: 13, Cree: 95] and as a gargle for sore throat [Dene: 13]. Boiled to make an external wash or bath for sore body parts [Dene: 17]. Medicinal [Chipewyan: 92].
Leaves and stem: Infusion taken for sore throat [Cree: 95].
Fruits: Eaten to clean the blood. Boiled and drunk for cold [Dene: 17] or to cure urinary tract problems and constipation [Dene: 101]. Boiled and taken as a cough medicine [Dene: 98].
Leaves: Crushed and applied to bee stings and burns [Dene: 100].

Vernacular name(s): hobblebush (Eng.); viorne à feuilles d'aulne, bois d'orignal (Fr.); mistatiteminatuk (Atikamekw)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Leaves: Crushed and rubbed on head to fight headache [Atikamekw: 73].

Vernacular name(s): sheepberry, nannyberry, (Eng.); viorne lentago, alisier, bourdaine (Fr.); teta-minan, atîte' (Ojibwa);
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Leaves: Steeped and drunk as a remedy for dysuria. Poultice bound on the abdomen, over the bladder [Ojibwa: 85].
Roots: Steeped and taken to trigger menstruation, sometimes mixed with Canada lily [Malecite: 65].
Inner bark: Tea used as a diuretic [Ojibwa: 87].

Vernacular name(s): cranberries, flat seed berries, moose berry (Eng.); viorne obier (Fr.)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Fruits: Steeped and drunk for swollen glands [Mi'kmaq: 60, Algonquians: 63] and mumps [Algonquians: 63]. Boiled and the mess rubbed in the eyes for sore eyes [Algonquians: 63].
Bark: Decoction used as a diuretic [66].

Latin name, Botanical family and Growth: Viburnum opulus L. var. americanum Aiton
Vernacular name(s): Bush cran berry (Eng.); viorne trilobée (Fr.); nepiminana, nīpiminān (Cree); a'nibîmî'nûga'wûck (Ojibwa)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Roots: Steeped and drunk as a remedy for pralapsus uteri. Part of the treatment consists of soaking a white cloth in an infusion and placing it in the vagina to put the uterus back into place [Ojibwa: 85].
Bark: Tea used as a diuretic, given to mothers after birth to prevent infection [Dene: 13], also given to treat insomnia [Dene, Metis: 13].
Inner bark: Tea used as a physic and to cure stomach cramps [Ojibwa: 87].

Vernacular name(s): stag-bush sloe (Eng.); viorne à feuilles de cerisier (Fr.)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Tea given to women before and after parturition [Mi'kmaq: 43].

Vernacular name(s): field pansy (Eng.); violette de Rafinesque (Fr.)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Whole plant: Infusion used to treat blood-shot eyes [Mi'kmaq: 62].

Vernacular name(s): Canada violet (Eng.); violette du Canada (Fr.); maskwī'widzhī'wiko'kŏk (Ojibwa)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Roots: Decoction taken for bladder pain [Ojibwa: 66, 84].

Vernacular name(s): American dog violet, alpine violet (Eng.); violette du Labrador (Fr.); wewaîe'bûgûg (Ojibwa)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Whole plant: Tea given for heart trouble [Ojibwa: 87].

Vernacular name(s): downy yellow violet (Eng.); violette pubescente (Fr.); ogitē'waguns (Ojibwa)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Roots: Decoction taken in sore throat [Ojibwa: 66, 84].

Vernacular name(s): wild grape (Eng.); vigne sauvage (Fr.); šiwi-min (Ojibwa)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Roots and branches: Steeped with roots of Ceanothus and Hepatica, bark of beech, and inner bark of sugar maple, black birch, and red-osier dogwood to make a remedy for pulmonary trouble [Ojibwa: 85].
Sap: Used as a tonic to wash hair [Ojibwa: 85].

Vernacular name(s): frost grape, river-bank grape (Eng.); vigne des renards (Fr.); ci'wî mînûn, jo'mĭnaga'wûnj (Ojibwa)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Twigs: Tea used to clear up afterbirth and enable it to pass easily [Ojibwa: 87].
Sap: Used for stomach and bowel trouble [Ojibwa: 87].
Roots: Steeped and taken to treat rheumatism and diabetes [Ojibwa: 47].

Vernacular name(s): prickly ash (Eng.); clavalier d'Amérique, frêne épineux (Fr.); dagawak-mins, gawa'komĭc (Ojibwa)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Bark: Hot drink together with wild ginger root, bark of sassafras roots, and rhizomes of sweet flag, taken for cold, cough, and pulmonary troubles [Ojibwa: 85]. Tea drunk for worms [Mi'kmaq: 62]. Used to treat quinsy and sore throat [Ojibwa: 87].
Roots: Decoction used to treat sore throat [Ojibwa: 47].
Fruits: Tea drunk to treat sore throat, and as a spray on the chest to cool and relieve congestion in bronchitis [Ojibwa: 87].

Vernacular name(s): wildrice (Eng.); zizanie aquatique, folle avoine, riz sauvage (Fr.); manomin (Ojibwa)
Part(s) used, Use(s) and Reference(s): Roots: Used for urinary infection and diabetes [Ojibwa: 89].
